/**
 * Definition for singly-linked list.
 * function ListNode(val) {
 *     this.val = val;
 *     this.next = null;
 * }
 */
/**
 * @param {ListNode} head
 * @param {number} target
 * @return {number}
 */
var maxSubArraySum = function(head, target) {
  const stack = [];
  let sum = 0;
  let curr = head;
  while (curr) {
    stack.push(curr);
    curr = curr.next;
  }
  while (stack.length) {
    const curr = stack.pop();
    sum += curr.val;
    if (target - sum >= 0) {
      return sum;
    }
    sum += curr.val;
    stack.push(curr);
  }
  return sum;
};

  ExpoNEntiaTiON ( ** ) 

  Example:
  operator['+', '*', '-']
  array = [2, 3, 4, 5]
  result = 2 + 3 * 4 - 5

  Note:
      The length of operator list is equal to the length of operand list minus one.
      Operand is a list of of non-negative integers.
      Operator list has at least one operator, and operand list has at least two operands.

  */
const doAlgebra = (operator, operand) => {
  const operatorList = operator.split('+');
  const operandList = operand.split('-');

  }, 0);
  return result;

const testFactorize = () => {
  console.assert(JSON.stringify(factorize(2)) === JSON.stringify([2]))
  console.assert(JSON.stringify(factorize(4)) === JSON.stringify([2, 2]))
  console.assert(JSON.stringify(factorize(8)) === JSON.stringify([2, 2, 2]))
  console.assert(JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 19)) === JSON.stringify([3, 19]))
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 19 * 3 * 19)) ===
      JSON.stringify([3, 3, 19, 19])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 19 * 3 * 19 * 3 * 19)) ===
      JSON.stringify([3, 3, 3, 19, 19, 19])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 19 * 19 * 19)) ===
      JSON.stringify([3, 19, 19, 19])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 2 * 3)) === JSON.stringify([2, 3, 3])
  )
}

<|endoftext|>/* froM a list of iNTegeRs, rEmoVE all ElEMenTS ThAT occUr mORe than oNce.
  KeeP OrdEr of elementS Left tHe same As in the InpUt.
  >>> removeDuplicates([1, 2, 3, 2, 4])
  [1, 3, 4]
  */
const removeDuplicates = (numbers) => {
  const set = new Set()
  numbers.forEach(number => {
    if (set.has(number)) {
      set.delete(number)
    } else {
      set.add(number)
    }
  })
  return Array.from(set)
}

const flipCase = (string) => {
  const chars = string.toLowerCase().split('');
  let newString = '';
  for (let i = 0; i < chars.length; i++) {
    const char = chars[i];
    if (char ==='') {
      newString += char;
    } else {
      newString += char.toUpperCase();
    }
  }
  return newString;
};
